results.title: Purplish red crown = Zi se de huang guan
results.creator_credit: Chen Renjin, Yu Benzheng and Shanghai Film Studio
results.brief_description:
The film takes place over the course of a single day.

Taxi driver Zhan works hard for little money. One morning he picks up Chen, a film director, and his manager Xing, to take them to a production meeting for an uninspired film. Returning to the taxi with the men, Zhan discovers that it has been vandalised. He is distraught, knowing that he cannot afford to pay for the repairs. His boss chastises him, fining Zhan even though he knows that he cannot afford it.

Wao Xiaobing, a young and mischievous boy, is the culprit. Plagued by memories of a soldier, whom we later learn is his father, the boy wonders the streets, keying cars in a miserable attempt to attract attention. On the morning that he keys Zhan’s taxi he is caught keying a second car nearby, and Zhan lashes out against the boy. Throwing him in the taxi, he threatens to take the child home and demand the money for his hefty fine. Though not before they make a few stops for the two businessmen. Along the way, Zhan antagonises the boy, who becomes increasingly distressed. Discovering a photo of his father in his pocket, Zhan calls the soldier insignificant. Upset and defensive, the boy declares that his father was a Rank 23 Cadre who served in Xingjiang. Chen, the director, befriends the boy, listening intently as he shares stories of the brave soldier. Interested in the boy’s story, Chen hopes to discover the motive for his mischievous behaviour.

The group stops at the Athletic Centre to meet with Coach Su for advice on a film script, which she criticises as a stereotypical story of struggle and success. Coach Su, coincidentally, is Wao Xiaobing’s former teacher, and she tells the men that his veteran father has divorced his mother and moved to another district, and that his mother has now remarried. The boy’s familial story provides inspiration to Chen’s dull script, and the men decide to probe him for more information. Through a series of flashbacks, we gradually learn more about Wao Xiaobing’s past and his relationship with his father. One flashback, prompted by the passing of an ambulance, takes us to the snowy mountains of Xingjiang, and shows his father being loaded into an ambulance on a gurney.

On the next stop, the men seek the advice of the film’s lead actress Wang Jingping, who expresses her excitement at the strength, independence and modernity of the female lead. Meanwhile, through flashbacks of his elderly and ill aunt, we receive an insight into the character of Director Chen, who has issues of his own to cope with. When they return to the car after the meeting, they find that Wao Xiaobing has escaped, apparently driven away by Zhan’s ill-tempered threats. While Chen and his manager worry about the safety of the boy, Zhan maintains his anger. They search the city for him, and learn from a gathered crowd that a young boy fitting Wao Xiaobing’s description has been hit by a car. Panicking, the men run to the nearest hospital to find him, but are not allowed into the operating theatre. Disguising themselves as doctors, they sneak in and encounter a number of doctors working furiously on the boy. The child, however, is not Wao Xiaobing. Relieved, the men frantically continue their search, having formed a bond with the boy. When they return to the car, they find Wao Xiaobing asleep next to it. They scold the boy for worrying them, and he explains that he wanted to go home but didn’t know the way. Explaining to the men that he has lost the treasured photograph of his father, he agrees to continue with them in the hopes of getting it back.

Chen reaches out to Wao Xiaobing, who tells him that he feels homesick and out of place in his new home. His new stepfather doesn’t allow him to see his real father, causing Wao to vandalise cars out of heartache and frustration. He reveals that he is supposed to meet his father in the town square in a couple of hours, and requests the help of Zhan to get him there. They face a series of obstacles along the way and are caught in a storm, heavy traffic, and the crossing of a cargo train. When they finally arrive at the monument, Wao’s father is nowhere to be seen. They wait, desperately, but he never arrives. Wao is devastated. Chen sympathetically tells him that while he may hate living with his mother and stepfather now, he will eventually understand.

Finally, Wao Xiaobing asks to be taken home, but along the way he spots his father and jumps out of the car. He searches the streets for him frantically, enlisting the help of Zhan. Unsuccessful, they take the boy home, but he is hesitant to go, having formed a bond with the men. Upon witnessing the emotional goodbye between Xiaobing and Zhan, the producer has a brainwave for a new film, jotting down what is assumed to be the story of the day’s events.
(3.5 stars - Aleena Glentis; August 9, 2012)

results.title: Purple silken mist = Kabut sutra ungu
results.creator_credit: Sjumandjaja, M Sukmadjaya, Dharma Effendy and Matari Artis Jaya Film
results.brief_description: Russian-trained director Sjuman Djaya depicts a story of the social stigma faced by a young widow in middle-class Jakarta. Jenny Rachman plays the pretty wife who is left widowed when her pilot husband dies suddenly. After being taunted by several other men she takes a liking to Dimas, her late husband’s younger brother, who bears a striking resemblance to him. Dimas starts to replace his brother as the young children mistake him for their dead father. The children’s mother however resists Dimas’ marriage proposal for fear that it is not true love that has brought them together. Winner of 4 Citra Awards at the 1990 FFI. Cast includes Jenny Rachman, Roy Marten and Joice Erna. In Indonesion with English subtitles that are sometimes difficult to read.

results.title: Pure steam: The Flying Scotsman in Australia (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Peter Henshaw, Jim Revitt and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: For almost a year the world’s most famous working steam locomotive, The Flying Scotsman 4472, from Britain, thrilled Australian steam enthusiasts from coast to coast. During 1988/89 4472 visited five Australian states and the Northern Territory. Its spectacular parallel runs, double-heading and solo trips have been brilliantly recorded by camera crews from ABC TV, from the air, trackside and on board.

results.title: Puppet animation
results.creator_credit: David Johnson, Eric Halliday, Mark Sanders, Nancy Wahlquist and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A sequel to “The Animation game” (T/Code 015386) that examines and demonstrates the many possibilities of puppet animation. Produced in a humorous and stylistically appealing manner. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Punk in London
results.brief_description: Originally shot in colour 16mm film, this DVD edition has some of the hallmarks of an old print - scratches, pink tinge in the colour and generally dubious quality. But all of this can be forgiven, as the content of the work is a wonderful documentary of live footage of concerts of UK punk bands given in late 1970s London and Germany. Features bands The Clash, The Adverts, The Jam, The Boomtown Rats, The Electric Chairs and others. Includes interviews, shots of street-wear fashion and crowds, including loving audiences pogo-ing with great delight and alcohol fuelled fervour. This film captures the youth of the day and their quest to make themselves seen and heard, singing “Oh Bondage, Up Yours!” Directed by Wolfgang Buld from the Munich Film School. (Please note a small glitch occurs at 00:09:57 min).

results.title: Public hangings. Series 2. Ep. 11
results.brief_description: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program (now in its second series) produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Andrew MacKenzie deviates from the program’s usual format to incorporate an in-depth interview with English artist, art critic, writer and television producer, Matthew Collings on the eve of his Australian lecture tour, 2002. Collings provides a refreshing and challenging outlook on contemporary art and provides contextual observation on contemporary art values and practice. Collings is best known for the BBC series ‘This is Modern Art’ and his book ‘Crazy Nation’ amongst others. Screen Talk this week looks at the work of Geneine Honey and includes an interview with excerpts from ‘Young Sad Love’ and ‘Don’t Go Out Walking’.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 2. Ep. 10
results.brief_description: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program (now in its second series) produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Andrew MacKenzie interviews Juliana Enberg, director of the Australian Centre for Contemporary Art (ACCA) at the opening of it’s new building at Southbank and inaugural exhibition by Susan Norrie ‘A History of Happiness’. The American artist Steve Keene exhibits his latest work at Linden gallery with the claim as being ‘the most prolific artist in America’. His work pokes fun at the age of “mechanical” reproduction and technologically driven work. Sandra Bridie, artist in residence at Tower Studio discusses her project ‘6 Contextual Modules’ and discusses her ongoing solo practise where Bridie presents herself as a multiple of fictional artists. Dominic Lococo discusses F4, a new multi-media space. Screen Talk: Brendan Lee discusses “Projekt”, the first quarterly journal in VHS format and presents excerpts including ‘Test’ by Sanja Pahoki, ‘The Bong Relay Business’ by TV Moore and ‘Container’ by Stephen Honeggar and Anthony Hunt.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 2. Ep. 08
results.brief_description: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program (now in its second series) produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. This episode first up visits Jawbone Wetlands Nature Reserve to look at the source of inspiration of Caroline Oxley’s exhibition of paintings ‘Return To Jawbone’, exhibited at Fitzroy Gallery. Kathy Temin in ‘Kylie Night’ explores her ongoing fascination with the pop-princess-phenomenon of Kylie Minogue and the culture of identity fetishism. Collaborators Christos Linou and Robert Mangion interweave the disciplines of performance, visual arts and film making to perform and exhibit the third part of their series of work ‘The Act Of Being Inside Out’ at Mass Gallery and the County Court in Melbourne. Curated by Stuart Koop at Monash University Museum of Art is the group show ‘Gulliver’s Travels’ that seeks to explore the recent popularity of model making and the miniature in Australian art. The exhibition includes: Craige Andre, Matt Calvert, Richard Giblett, Callum Morton, Louise Paramor, Ricky Swallow and Tim Silver. Screen Talk shows an excerpt from ‘S-Crash’ by Lindsay Cox and Victor Holder.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 2. Ep. 06
results.brief_description: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program (now in its second series) produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Andrew MacKenzie continues his “find an artist series” and heads off to Sunshine to discover the art of tattooing. In Glen Iris Sally Miller and Stephen Oakes present ‘Stakes and Ladders’, a collaborative exhibition that explores the cultural history of Vietnam. At Lab X ‘The Picture Show’ is presented. A group show coordinated by David Marks that explores the link between cinema and photography - exhibitors include: David Marks, Natascha Stellmach (‘Beyond Bollywood’), Lex Middleton, Gary Hillberg and Lawrence Johnstone. Johnstone’s work ‘All About Eve’ explores the processes involved in the construction of a film that remain either invisible or unused. This week’s Screen Talk looks at Gary Hillberg’s “compilation” tapes with excerpts from: ‘Shadows’, ‘Mirrors’, ‘Smoking’, and ‘Last Dance’. His body of work explores the relationship between the ‘home viewer’ and their private collected cinematic memories using low-tech editing techniques.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 2. Ep. 04
results.brief_description: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program (now in its second series) produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Melbourne City Council invites artists to respond to the recent environmental ‘Real Conference’ held in Johannassburg. Artists Louise Lavarack and Briele Hansen talk about the collaborative process specifically in regards to their project that utilises the generic plastic shopping bag. At George Paton Gallery, Sharnie Shield exhibits malleable tectohedronic forms exploring spacial possibilities of geometry. Ken Wong curates the annual Gasworks Arts Inc. artists show “Out of the Dark”. Jeff Wassman and Jamieson Miller are interviewed. Screentalk this week presents the film and projection work of artist Briele Hansen. Her work explores water in its various states (ocean, raindrops) as a metaphor for passage, transition and the human connection to the world. Excerpts are shown from works: ‘Fluid connection’ and ‘Here’.
